metadata.title: Faster initiating olefin metathesis catalysts from introducing double bonds into cyclopropyl, cyclobutyl and cyclopentyl derivatives of Hoveyda-Grubbs precatalysts

Fig. 1 Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1 and its selected derivatives investigated earlier. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Derivatives of the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst studied in this work, including the atom numbering scheme used throughout this work. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Calculated free energies of activation (ΔG‡) and relative free energies of the precatalyst, activated catalyst and catalyst with the associated olefin of complexes 9, 13–15 and 26. All values are in kcal/mol and relative to the corresponding precatalyst. Here we see that 13 and 26 have both low barriers for activation, a low energy activated catalyst, and a low energy for association with olefin, making these systems the most promising. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Calculated free energies of activation (ΔG‡) and relative free energies of the precatalyst, activated catalyst and catalyst with the associated olefin of complexes 16–19 and 27. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Calculated free energies of activation (ΔG‡) and relative free energies of the precatalyst, activated catalyst and catalyst with the associated olefin of complexes 20–23, 25 and 28. Trzaskowski a ⁎ W.A. Goddard b K. Grela c a Centre of New Technologies, University of Warsaw, 02-097 Warszawa, Poland Centre of New Technologies University of Warsaw Warszawa 02-097 Poland b Materials and Process Simulation Center, California Institute of Technology, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA Materials and Process Simulation Center California Institute of Technology Pasadena CA 91125 USA c Faculty of Chemistry, University of Warsaw, 02-089 Warszawa, Poland Faculty of Chemistry University of Warsaw Warszawa 02-089 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract We have used the M06-D3 flavor of density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the structures and free energies of initiation for a series of Hoveyda-Grubbs-like complexes in which the isopropoxy part replaced by selected saturated or unsaturated derivatives of cyclopropane, cyclobutane and cyclopentane. We show that the introduction of the double bond into this part of the complex weakens the ruthenium-oxygen bond, creating a series of potential catalysts capable of fast initiation metathesis. The addition to the nitro group in the para position of the benzylidene part of the complex also creates a potentially highly efficient ruthenium catalyst. We demonstrate that the Gibbs free energy of activation correlates with various structural and computational parameters of the precatalyst, including the Ru-O bond strength and partial charges on selected atoms. Keywords DFT Olefin metathesis Ruthenium Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst Double-bond 1 Introduction The second generation Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1, first synthesized in 2000, was one of the first efficient, phosphine-free ruthenium-based metathesis catalysts and which is still widely used today [1,2]. One of the most important advantages of 1 is the relative ease of introducing structural modifications to various parts of the catalyst to tune its electronic properties and catalytic activity. There three most important classes of such modifications include structural adjustments in the carbene part, the benzylidene part, and the isopropoxy moiety [3–5]. The changes in the isopropoxy part of 1 may have a particularly pronounced effect on the catalytic activity of Hoveyda-Grubbs-like catalysts. Grela showed that a simple substitution of the isopropoxy moiety with a methyl group (2) makes the catalyst much less active than 1 [6]. The same investigation found, however, that the introduction of ethylbenzene (3) or ethyl-para-nitrobenzene (4) improves catalytic activity, although it also reduces the stability of such complexes. The attempt to synthesize the CF3-substituted complex was unsuccessful. In 2009 the same group reported a dimethylpropanoic acid substitution (5), though no catalytic activity was reported [7]. Consorti et al. showed that the isopropoxy moiety can be replaced by ionophilic groups (6) and immobilized in ionic liquids without losing catalytic activity [8]. More recently, Grela and Lavigne synthesized a series of Hoveyda-Grubbs derivatives generated from monofunctionalized styrenyl ethers that exhibit improved catalytic properties (7) [9]. A similar set of complexes that included additional Ru-O interaction has been synthesized in 2014 in Wang group and shown to exhibit relatively fast initiation in ring-closing metathesis [10,11]. Also, a series of 2-aryloxy Hoveyda-Grubbs complexes (8) synthesized in the Plenio group showed excellent stability and fast initiation at low temperatures [12]. Finally, the most recent example of isopropoxy modification is the study by the Grubbs group, which synthesized and characterized four new, efficient Hoveyda-Grubbs derivatives including bulky, saturated groups (9-12) [13] (Fig. 1 ). Based on the seminal work by Plenio, who showed that the precatalyst activation/initiation is the rate-limiting step of the entire catalytic cycle for Hoveyda-Grubbs-like catalysts [14,15] and recent advances in density functional theory with modern functionals accurately describing organometallic systems and subtle van der Waals interactions [16–18], more and more groups have been using computational modelling to study olefin metathesis catalysts [19–24]. The mechanism of the entire catalytic cycle of olefin metathesis for Hoveyda-Grubbs-like catalysts has been described thoroughly in a number of computational studies, which show excellent agreement with experimental data [25–28]. There are three theoretically plausible initiation paths for the Hoveyda-Grubbs-type catalysts: associative, dissociative, and interchange. In the associative path, which in most cases has the highest free enthalpy barrier [29] making it very unlikely, activation of the precatalyst starts with olefin association followed by Ru1-O1 bond dissociation. The dissociative path is opposite starting with Ru1-O1 bond dissociation followed by olefin association. In the third, interchange mechanism both events occur simultaneously. The recent experimental and computational results suggest that the dissociative mechanism is the most favorable option for the case of large and moderate olefins, but for very small olefins the initiation may follow either the dissociative, interchange or both mechanisms in parallel [14,15]. As a result, for most cases of practical importance in organic synthesis one needs only consider the dissociative mechanism as the likely initiation pathway for any new, hypothetical precatalysts, particularly for ruthenium complexes that are structurally similar to 1 and 9. Many computational estimates for the free energy barrier of activating metathesis catalysts, including Hoveyda-Grubbs-like systems, are accurate to within 1–2kcal/mol [30,31]. Such accuracy allows us to predict reliably the initiation rates for this class of catalysts and their overall usefulness in olefin metathesis prior to their synthesis. Due to this high accuracy of the theoretical methods, we can now use the computational results to guide synthetic chemists in preparation of new catalysts most likely to be active or to contributing a better understanding of the structure-activity relationships for this class of compounds. In this work we used such a reliable DFT-based approach to study computationally a set of 16 new derivatives of 9. Prior to starting this investigation, we estimated the free energy barrier (ΔG‡) of initiation of 9 using the M06-D3/LACVP** method to be ΔG‡ =21.7kcal/mol. The experimental estimate for the reaction rate of 9 at 10°C is 0.721±0.004·10−4 s−1, which based on the Eyring equation, leads to 21.9kcal/mol, in perfect agreement with the experiment [13]. The newly designed candidates for catalysts included selected cycloalkane derivatives replacing the cyclopropane moiety of 9, including cyclopropene (13–15), cyclobutane (16), cyclobutene (17–18), cyclobutadiene (19), cyclopentane (20), cyclopentene (21–23) and cyclopentadiene (24–25). Additionally, we performed calculations for three cycloalkane derivatives bearing a nitro group in the para position of the benzylidene moiety, similarly to the very fast Grela nitro catalyst (26–28) [32]. For each complex we predicted its geometric and electronic structure and estimated the free energy barriers for the metathesis initiation step, which we compared with the original Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst. We also searched for structure-reactivity relationships that could further guide experimental chemists in identifying new, efficient metathesis catalysts for synthesis (Fig. 2 ). 2 Methods 2.1 Computational details Throughout this work we have used a computational protocol similar to our previous computational investigations, shown earlier to be a good choice for studying ruthenium catalysts of olefin metathesis [30,31,33–37]. Starting models of precatalysts were prepared on the basis of the crystal structure of 9 (CCDC refcode: WUJCAH) [13], while the starting structures of all other stationary points were prepared based on our previous calculations and geometries of stationary points for similar systems [30,33]. We have used an all-atom model for all studied catalysts and the cis-2-butene molecule to model the substrate of olefin metathesis. For each stationary point we have confirmed that all vibration frequencies are positive for minima and that only one is imaginary for transition states. For the geometry optimization step we used the 6–31G** basis set for C, N, O, Cl and H atoms, while the Ru atom was described by the Los Alamos angular momentum projected effective core potential (ECP) using the double-ζ contraction of valence functions (denoted as LACVP**) [17]. All calculations used the standard energy convergence criterion of 5×10−5 Hartree. Additionally, for each stationary point we performed solvation calculations using the Poisson-Boltzmann self-consistent polarizable continuum method as implemented in Jaguar v.7.9 (Schrodinger, 2013) to represent dichloromethane, using the dielectric constant of 8.93 and the effective radius 2.33Å. We also performed single-point energy calculations using a triple-ζ basis set, LACV3P++**. Free energies were defined as the sum of electronic energy (from single-point M06-D3/LACV3P++** calculations), solvation energy, zero-point energy correction, thermal correction to enthalpy, and the negative product of temperature and entropy (at 298K). In this study we have used the M06-D3 density functional, which was previously shown to be a good choice for studying ruthenium-based catalysts, giving accurate energies for a number of Grubbs and Hoveyda systems [38,39]. The M06 functional already includes some medium-range dispersion, but the D3 parameter in M06-D3 was chosen to reflect this. Indeed including the D3 correction to M06 was shown to improve the results for many organic reactions when calculating the differences in relative energies [17]. Based on out previous results and benchmarks provided by other groups we can estimate the accuracy of the used method to fall around the 1–2kcal/mol range [17]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural studies The DFT-optimized geometries of complexes 13-28 are presented in Table 1 and compared to systems 1 and 9. As in our previous studies and investigations by other groups we see very little variability in the vital structural parameters of these systems [13,33,34,37]. There are, however, some differences that have potentially important consequences regarding initiation. The Ru-O distance varies between 2.29 and 2.37Å (2.30Å for 9) suggesting that some complexes have a weaker Ru-O bond, which implies easier Ru-O bond breaking and faster initiation. There is also some variability in the O1-C5 bond length, with values between 1.34Å (for systems with a double bond next to the C5 atom) and 1.45Å (for systems without the neighboring double bond). These values also impact the partial charges on the O1 and C5 atoms. The O1 Mulliken and natural partial charges are almost identical for all systems, but the ESP charges show fluctuations between −0.20 and −0.57 e. On the other hand, C5 partial charges show a range of values for all three methods of estimating charges. There are also non-negligible relationships between these mentioned distances and partial charges, including a negative correlation between the Ru-O distance and C5 ESP charge (R2 =0.27), as well as strong correlations between O1-C5 distance and C5 NBO charge (R2 =0.82), O1 NBO charge (R2 =0.82), C5 Mulliken charge (R2 =0.81) and O1 ESP charge (R2 =0.43), which are mostly obvious from the structural point of view. On the other hand, there is no (R2 =0.00) correlation between the Ru1-C1 and Ru1-O1 bond lengths, which might have been expected due to the known trans effect [33,34,40–42]. These results indicate, however, that there might be some rational relationships between selected structural parameters and free energy of initiation, which we describe in the next section. Hoveyda-Grubbs-like complexes exhibit also cis-trans isomerism, which may have important consequences on their catalytic activity. Goddard and coworkers showed that the trans-chloride isomer of 1 is characterized by much lower free energy barriers than for cis for most steps in the catalytic cycle, including the rate-limiting ones [39]. The trans isomer is favored for most of the commonly used Ru-based metathesis catalysts, though cis isomers also have their uses. A number of similar compounds with a different NHC and other structural modification can adopt such conformation [28,43]. In the case of complexes 13-28 the trans isomer is favored over the cis one for most systems, excluding 13 and 21. For these two cases the free energy difference is, however, very small (−2.38kcal/mol for 13 and −0.15kcal/mol for 21), suggesting that both isomers may co-exist in the solution. The free energy difference between cis and trans isomers is, however, also small for some other studied complexes, ranging from 0.19kcal/mol (for 16) to 5.04kcal/mol (for 23). These values are much lower than for the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1, where the trans isomer is 8.5kcal/mol lower in energy than cis [37], resulting in almost exclusive presence of the trans isomer in the solution. 3.2 Performance in metathesis initiation The Gibbs free energy barriers for activation of 9 and 13–28 are presented in Fig. 3 . We see that the ΔG‡ values fall within the broad 12.84–23.89kcal/mol range, suggesting that some of these systems can be very fast metathesis initiators, while some are on the level of or slower than the standard Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1. To better characterize the structure-reactivity relationships between the complexes and the impact of the presence of the double-bond, we decided to partition the systems into three groups based on the size of the cyclic moiety. The first group is composed of cyclopropane/cyclopropene derivatives of 1 and consists of five complexes: 9, 13–15 and 26 (Fig. 3). Previously synthesized complex 9 is a relatively slow catalyst, on the level of the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1 [13]. Our calculations suggest that the introduction of the double bond to the cyclopropane part of the system lowers the Gibbs free energy barrier of activation substantially (21.72–15.82–19.09kcal/mol). According to these results 13 is the fastest catalyst in the non-nitro catalysts with the ΔG‡ value of 15.8kcal/mol, which at 10°C should translate into approximately 50,000 faster activation compared to 9. Complex 14 with the ΔG‡ value of 18.1kcal/mol seems to be also a good candidate for a relatively quickly-initiating catalyst, with estimated initiation rate constant of 0.6×10−1 s−1. On the other hand, complex 15 with the double bond located further from the C5 atom seems to initiate similarly to 9 (ΔG‡ =19.09kcal/mol). Finally, the nitro-substituted complex 26 is characterized by the ΔG‡ value of 15.49kcal/mol, indicating very fast initiation on the level of the 3rd generation Grubbs complex [44,31]. This result is expected, since the introduction of the nitro group to the benzylidene moiety in the para position is known to enhance the initiation rate, although not to this large an extent [32]. Modification of the cyclopropane moiety (9) to a cyclobutane moiety (16) produces a precatalyst with essentially the same initiation ΔG‡ value (21.7kcal/mol versus 22.1kcal/mol). The introduction of the double bond yields similar results as in the previous case (Fig. 4 ). Complexes with the double bond directly next to the C5 atom are characterized by small ΔG‡ values (13.9kcal/mol for 17 and 14.9kcal/mol for 19), while complexes with the double bond located further from the C5 atom yield initiation rates similar to the complex without the double bond (21.0kcal/mol for 18). Interestingly, the addition of the para-nitro group (27) makes the cyclobutane complex more active (ΔG‡ =19.7kcal/mol), but to a smaller extent than in the case of the cyclopropane derivative. Using the well-known Eyring equation we can translate these Gibbs free energy values into estimated initiation rates at 10°C to obtain the following estimates of the reaction rates: 0.5×10−4 s−1 for 16, 1×102 s−1 for 17, 0.7×10−3 s−1 for 18, 2×101 s−1 for 19 and 0.4×10−2 s−1 for 27. Finally, we modified the cyclopropyl part of 9 with cyclopentane, cyclopentene, or cyclopentadiene moieties to obtain complexes 20–25 and 28 (Fig. 5 ). As in the previous examples the substituents with no double bond (20) or with one/two double bonds far from the C5 atom (22, 23, 25) produce complexes with estimated ΔG‡ initiation values of approximately 20kcal/mol, on the level of the standard Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1. On the other hand, complex 21 with the double bond at C5 is the fastest initiating catalyst of this study with the ΔG‡ =12.8kcal/mol, translating to 8×102 s−1. Intriguingly, the addition of the nitro group to the benzylidene part to produce 28 does not alter the ΔG‡ value (the difference between 20 and 28 of 0.4kcal/mol is negligible). This somewhat unexpected result is already pronounced at the precatalyst level. The analysis of the O1 and C5 ESP partial charges for the cyclopropane-substituted series reveals relatively large differences between cyclopropane series (O1: −0.41, C5: −0.03 for 9, O1: −0.31, C5: −0.15 for 26), but much smaller differences in the cyclopentane series (O1: −0.46, C5: 0.17 for 20, O1: −0.41, C5: 0.15 for 28). For the last complex in this series, namely 24, we do not provide Gibbs free energies estimates, since our calculations suggest that this system is unstable. While the calculations for the precatalyst converge and suggest that the expected structure is stable, optimization of the transition state converges to a completely different structure with a bicyclic ring. Such a structure is probably a result of strong interaction between the cylcopentadiene double bond and the Ru center, similar to the case of olefin association to ruthenium ion. Thus we believe that the complex is unstable. A related point to consider here is, however, the stability of all hypothetical complexes investigated in this work. Unfortunately our standard computational approach with implicit solvent not provide an estimate for the kinetic stability of the complexes in solution. A computational study of all possible degradation paths in standard solvents is, not feasible due to the limited knowledge about these processes for Hoveyda-Grubbs-like complexes. To sum it up, we cannot be certain that every complexes studied here is stable (particularly with 3- and 4-membered ring), but the known stability of similar systems forming complexes with transition metals and the experimental stability of 9 indicates that these complexes may be stable [45–47]. On a related note, it is worth noticing that the synthesis of some of the investigated complexes may be a challenging task. Most of Hoveyda-Grubbs-like an Grela-like catalysts are synthesized from the Grubbs 2nd generation catalyst, which itself is a potent metathesis catalysts, via replacement of the PCy3 moiety with a benzylidene precursor. As a result it is likely that some for some the studied systems, particularly 15, 18, 19, 22 and 23, their precursors may undergo a ring-opening metathesis polymerization in the presence of the Grubbs 2nd generation catalyst, before the synthesis of the desired complex takes place. In these cases an alternative synthetic approach starting e.g. from an easy to handle precursor [(p-cymene)RuCl2]2 and without presence of any phosphine ligand could a viable options. We should also mention that some of the Gibbs free energy values for initiation, via Ru1-O1 bond dissociation are so low that initiation is likely not the rate-limiting step of the entire catalytic cycle. The experimental initiation rate for one of the fastest derivative of Hoveyda-Grubbs analogue, the Blechert-Wakamatsu catalyst, is equal to 3.4s−1 at 25°C, giving the ΔG‡ of initiation equal to 16.7kcal/mol [48]. On the other hand the estimated ΔG barriers of selected steps after olefin association in the metathesis catalytic cycle of 1 are between 15 and 17kcal/mol [29]. Since all complexes studied in this work are structurally similar to 1 we should expect that for all complexes in this study with the ΔG‡ values below 16–17kcal/mol, including 13, 17, 19, 21 and 26, the true reaction rate are lower than the initiation rate estimates and in the range of approximately 0.5×10−1 s−1–1.5×101 s−1. The second, important goal of this study was to investigate the possible relationships between selected structural parameters of these precatalysts with the predicted ΔG‡ values to find relationships that could be helpful for future i designs of potent metathesis catalysts. In recent studies Engle et al. found an interesting negative correlation between the initiation rates and the Ru1-O1 bond strengths (defined as the energy difference between the activated catalysts and the precatalyst) for a large series of Hoveyda-Grubbs derivatives [13]. We recently analyzed a series of computationally designed coumarin derivatives of 1 and found a similar correlation [49], although a different series of benzofuran derivatives of 1 did not show such correlation [37]. Due to these findings we decided to examine correlations between all structural and computational parameters listed in Table 1 for all investigated complexes (Fig. 6 ). First, the relationship between the initiation rates and Ru1-O1 bond strengths (as defined in Ref. [13]) is indeed present (R2 =0.68). This is an important result since it allows one to accurately estimate the precatalyst potential for the metathesis reaction by merely calculating the activated catalyst, which is much less time-consuming and complex than optimization of the transition state. For of our set of precatalysts there are also other strong correlations. Most notably, there is a strong negative correlation between the initiation ΔG‡ and the C5 Mulliken partial charge (R2 =0.59) and C5 NBO partial charge (R2 =0.54) as well as the O1 ESP partial charge (R2 =0.43) and O1 NBO partial charge (R2 =0.40). There are also some more surprising correlations, including the one between the initiation ΔG‡ and the C4 Mulliken partial charge (R2 =0.56) as well as the Ru1 ESP partial charge (R2 =0.48). The overall conclusions from this set of correlations is that an electron-rich group attached to the C5 atom modifies the electron density in such manner, that the C5 atom attains a positive partial charge, while the O1 atom becomes less negatively charged. This phenomenon, in turn, makes the Ru1-O1 bond weaker and allow for easier Ru1-O1 bond breaking, leading to faster initiation of the precatalyst. 4 Conclusions Despite the wealth of ruthenium-based metathesis catalysts and Hoveyda-Grubbs-like complexes in particular, there remains a need for new, efficient systems able to catalyze this important reaction. Since the mechanism of the entire catalytic cycle of metathesis is known, computational methods based on modern, very accurate DFT functionals, can be used to design new candidates for catalyst. From the computational point of view, the main difficulty in such studies is the optimization of transition states, which is a necessary step in estimating Gibbs free energies and rate constants. Consequently, it is useful to find indicators that are both easy and fast to calculate while providing a good estimate of the reaction (or at least initiation) rate. In this work we estimated the Gibbs free energies of activation for sixteen new derivatives of Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1 with the isopropyl moiety changed to various saturated and unsaturated cyclopropane, cyclobutane and cyclopentane substituents. We show that the introduction of the double bond to the C5 carbon atom, adjacent to the O1 oxygen atom coordinating the ruthenium center weakens the Ru-O bond, producing fast initiating complexes and candidates for efficient metathesis catalysts. For five new complexes (13, 17, 19, 21, 26) the estimated initiation ΔG‡ is below 16kcal/mol, suggesting a very fast initiation, on the level of 3rd generation, phosphorous-containing Grubbs catalyst. Two other complexes (14, 15) show initiation ΔG‡ values in the 18–19kcal/mol range, implying also fast initiation, on the level of the very efficient Grela nitro catalyst. Systems with the double bond positioned further from the O1 oxygen atom have minor impact on the energetics of the initiation step. We hope that these results will encourage experimental groups to synthesize the most promising complexes to experimentally test their catalytic activities. Additionally, we found several interesting relationships between the obtained Gibbs free energy of initiation values and selected structural and computational parameters of the precatalysts. First, we confirmed a previously known correlation between ΔG‡ values and Ru-O bond strengths, which allows for a relatively fast estimation of initiation free enthalpies through calculating only the energies of precatalysts and activated catalyst. Second, we found several interesting relationships between ΔG‡ values and partial charges on C5 and O1 atoms using different charge partitioning schemes. The ΔG‡-C5 partial charge correlation seems to be particularly useful when considering other structural modifications in the isopropyl part of the Hoveyda-Grubbs catalyst 1, allowing a very fast estimate of the complex potency in metathesis based on a single optimization of the precatalyst only. Acknowledgments This work was supported by the National Centre for Research and Development (grant SImPLeCAT to B.T. and K.G.). The calculations were partially performed at the Interdisciplinary Center for Mathematical and Computational Modelling (University of Warsaw) under G53-9 computational grant and at Caltech with support from NSF CHE 1214158. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2016.12.018. Appendix A Supplementary data The following is Supplementary data to this article: Geometric parameters, energies, regression plots, partial charges and Cartesian coordinates of all investigated systems. coredata.dc:description: We have used the M06-D3 flavor of density functional theory (DFT) to investigate the structures and free energies of initiation for a series of Hoveyda-Grubbs-like complexes in which the isopropoxy part replaced by selected saturated or unsaturated derivatives of cyclopropane, cyclobutane and cyclopentane. We show that the introduction of the double bond into this part of the complex weakens the ruthenium-oxygen bond, creating a series of potential catalysts capable of fast initiation metathesis. The addition to the nitro group in the para position of the benzylidene part of the complex also creates a potentially highly efficient ruthenium catalyst. We demonstrate that the Gibbs free energy of activation correlates with various structural and computational parameters of the precatalyst, including the Ru-O bond strength and partial charges on selected atoms.
coredata.dc:title: Faster initiating olefin metathesis catalysts from introducing double bonds into cyclopropyl, cyclobutyl and cyclopentyl derivatives of Hoveyda-Grubbs precatalysts
